citation.article-title: Gulosibacter molinativorax gen. nov., sp. nov., a molinate-degrading bacterium, and classification of 'Brevibacterium helvolum' DSM 20419 as Pseudoclavibacter helvolus gen. nov., sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Pseudoclavibacter (Pseu.do.cla′vi.bac.ter. Gr. adj. pseudes false; N.L. masc. n. Clavibacter a bacterial generic name; N.L. masc. n. Pseudoclavibacter false Clavibacter).
Chemo-organotrophic; various organic compounds are used as carbon and energy sources, including sugars, alcohols, organic acids and nitrogenated bases.
The peptidoglycan is B2γ [l-DAB]–d-glu–d-DAB (Schleifer & Kandler, 1972; Sasaki et al., 1998).
Menaquinone MK-9 is the major respiratory quinone.
Polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and an unknown glycolipid.
The predominant fatty acids are 12-methyl-tetradecanoic acid (anteiso-C15 : 0), 14-methyl-pentadecanoic acid (iso-C16 : 0) and 14-methyl-hexadecanoic acid (anteiso-C17 : 0).
Major polyamines are 1,3-diaminopropane and cadaverine (Altenburger et al., 1997).
The G+C content of DNA is about 67 mol%.
The type species is Pseudoclavibacter helvolus.
